Options.Value: Consistency
Materiality
Objectivity
Realization

Question 1.Question: The accounting principle that is applied to check arbitrary on the part of accountants is
Question 1.Explanation: Objectivity relates to the preparation of financial statement without any subjection i.e. it must contain facts. The objectivity principle is the concept that the financial statements of an organization be based on solid evidence. The intent behind this principle is to keep the management and the accounting department of an entity from producing financial statements that are slanted by their opinions and biases.

Options.Value: Decrease in current assets
An increase in liabilities and assets
A decrease in assets and capital
An increase in liabilities and a decrease in assets

Question 2.Question: The loss of equipment in a fire disaster results in
Question 2.Explanation: Equipment is an asset, the loss of equipment will result in reduction in assets as well as capital. A fixed asset is a long-term tangible piece of property or equipment that a firm owns and uses in its operations to generate income. Fixed assets are not expected to be consumed or converted into cash within a year.

Options.Value: Amount due to creditors
Actual cost of an asset
Selling price of goods
Amount due from debtors

Question 3.Question: A source document is used for verifying the
Question 3.Explanation: Selling price of a particular can be checked through the source document. Source documents are typically retained for use as evidence when auditors later review a company's financial statements, and need to verify that transactions have, in fact, occurred.

Options.Value: Liabilities
Equities
Assets
Capital

Question 4.Question: The rule of accounting equation requires that account payable should be placed under
Question 4.Explanation: Account payable are placed under liabilities while Account receivables are placed under Asset. Accounts Receivable is recorded under the category of assets, while Accounts Payable would be recorded under liabilities (read more about assets and liabilities and how they fit into the accounting equation).

Options.Value: N 2,100
N 2,200
N 4,400
N 6,400

Question 7.Question: A debit in the suspense account will appear in the balance sheet as
Question 7.Explanation: Since debit items on total balance are assets, it would appear on current side.

Question 8.Question: The recipient whose name appears on a cheque is called a
Question 8.Explanation: Payee is the recipient whose name appears in cheque. Payer is the person drawing or issuing a cheque to a payee. Drawer is the bank which the cheque is paid to. A payee is a party in an exchange who receives payment. The payee is paid by cash, check, or another transfer medium by a payer.

Options.Value: Ledger account
Bank account
Cash book
Petty cash

Question 9.Question: The imprest account is subsidiary to the
Question 9.Explanation: Petty cash book records expenses involving petty cash. Interest account is a subsidiary to this account.

Options.Value: Cash column
Discount column
Bank column
Folio column

Question 10.Question: The three-column cash book differs from the two-column cash book in
Question 10.Explanation: Discount column differentiated three columns from a two column cash book. The only difference between two types of cash book is that a double column cash book has two money columns (i.e., cash and bank) whereas a triple column cash book has three money columns (i.e., cash, bank and discount).

Question 11.Question:
Zakari started a business in January 2000. He bought a shop costing N 54,000 and stock worth N 7,600. Profit for the year amounted to N 22,100. His closing capital was N 73,800.

Zakari's personal drawings amounted to
Question 11.Explanation:
.NN
Closing capital.73,800
Add: Drawing.x
Less: Opening capital ..
Shop54,000.
Stock7,600.
.61,60061,600
Profit.22,100

= N (73,800 + x) - N 61,600 = N 22,100

= N (12,200 + x) = N 22,100

x = N (22,100 - 12,200)

x = N 9,900

Question 12.Question: The balance on the provision for depreciation account is
Question 12.Explanation: Provision for depreciation is debited to P & L a/c and deducted from the fixed asset in the balance. The use of a provision for depreciation account is an improvement over the accounting treatment of depreciation discussed on "accounting treatment of depreciation" page. This account is used to accumulate depreciation that is provided against a fixed asset.

Question 13.Question:
Given:

Rates paid during the year amounted to N 2,250 at N 125 per month and N 1,035 was paid for electricity in the same period at N 115 per month.

Determine the amount of prepaid rates.
Question 13.Explanation:
Rates = N 125 per month

Rate (1 year) = N 125 × 12 = N 1,500

Rate paid = N 2,250

Rate paid in advance = N (2,250 - 1,500) = N 750

Question 16.Question: Where closing stock is undervalued, the effect is
Question 16.Explanation:
Overstated stock will overcast the value of gross profit as under-valued stock will decrease its value. The impacts will be as follows:

- Closing stock figure in the current assets of balance sheet will be over-stated.

- Cost of Sales for the period will be under-stated.

- Gross Profit for the period will be over-stated.

- Net Profit will be overstated or Net Loss will be under-stated, etc.

Question 19.Question: In a sales ledger, contra entry is found on the
Question 19.Explanation: Contra entry is found on the credit side of the debtors control account in sales ledger. A contra entry journal is used to make the adjustment. The amount due from the customer has been posted to the accounts receivable ledger, whereas the amount due to the supplier is posted to the accounts payable ledger. The business has agreed with the customer that the balances are to be offset by contra entry.

Question 24.Question: The main objective of accounting report is to provide information about
Question 24.Explanation:
Foremost among the objectives of accounting and reporting is to provide useful information for management, investors, creditors, analysts, governments, and others.

Accounting information is general purpose and should be designed to serve the information needs of all types of interested parties.

Use the information below to answer the question.

On January 1, 2000, a clubs assets and liabilities were as follows:

.₦
Club house 8,000
Subscription in arrears300
Cash1,000
Wages owed100

The club has 50 members and annual subscription is N 100 per member. Subscription received is N4,000 and this includes 1999 arrears of N 200.

The accumulated fund is
Question 28.Explanation:
Asset = Accumulated Fund + Liabilities

N (8,000 + 1,000 + 300) = N (X + 100)

N (9,300 -100) = X

X = N 9,200

Accumulated Fund = N9,200

Question 29.Explanation:

= N 1,200

Question 30.Question: Where the debit side of the income and expenditure account is higher than the credit side, the difference is a
Question 30.Explanation:
Surplus occurs when the income side is greater than the expenditure side while deficit occurs when expenditure side is higher than the income side.

All expenditure is debited while all income are credited to the income and expenditure account.

Question 31.Question: In the balance sheet of a not-for-profit-making organization, subscription paid in advance is regarded as a
Question 31.Explanation: All income paid in advance are classified as current liability items. Current liabilities could also be based on an organization's operating cycle, which is the time it takes to buy inventory and convert it to cash from sales. Current liabilities are listed on the balance sheet under the liabilities section and are paid from the revenue generated from the operating activities of a company.

Joint venture accounts

Question 48.Question: According to the provisions of the 1999 constitution, all revenues generated by the Federal Government must be paid into the
Question 48.Explanation: Consolidated Revenue Fund records all revenue generated by the Federal Government. All revenues accruing to the Federal Government (after deductions) end up in the Federation account and forms part of revenue that is utilized in funding the national budget.

Question 49.Question: The budget statement presented to the legislature by the Chief Executive is called
Question 49.Explanation: Appropriation bill is the budget statement presented to the legislature by the chief executive. The legislature deliberates on it and approves it by passing it into law.

Funds flow statement of government

Question 50.Question: The statement of assets and liabilities in the public sector can be described as the
Question 50.Explanation: The statement of financial position of a public sector represents its fund flows statement. Cash flow information allows users to ascertain how a public sector entity raised the cash it required to fund its activities and the manner in which that cash was used.
